definition:
Let $X$ be a Hausdorff space and $f\colon X\to X$ a function. A point
$x\in X$ is said to be *recurrent* (for $f$) if $x\in \omega(x)$, i.e.
if $x$ belongs to its $\omega$- set. This means that for each
neighborhood $U$ of $x$ there exists $n>0$ such that $f^n(x)\in U$.

The closure of the set of recurrent points of $f$ is often denoted
$R(f)$ and is called the *recurrent set* of $f$.

Every recurrent point is a nonwandering point, hence if $f$ is a
homeomorphism and $X$ is compact, $R(f)$ is an invariant subset of
$\Omega(f)$, which may be a proper subset.
